{{also|Dort|dört}} ==English== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|en|enm|dort}} (found in compound {{m|enm|cankerdort}}), of unknown origin. ===Pronunciation=== * {{rhymes|en|ɔː(ɹ)t}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|UK|_|dialectal|Northern England|Scotland}} A [[sulky]] or [[sullen]] [[mood]]; the [[sulks]]. ====Usage notes==== * Usually used in the plural, ''the dorts''. ====Derived terms==== * {{l|en|dorty}} ===Verb=== {{en-verb}} # {{lb|en|intransitive}} To become [[pettish]]; [[sulk]]. ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=dort|dtor|trod}} ---- ==Czech== ===Etymology=== {{der|cs|de|Torte}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{cs-IPA}} * {{audio|cs|Cs-dort.ogg|audio}} ===Noun=== {{cs-noun|g=m}} # [[cake]] ====Declension==== {{cs-decl-noun |dort|dortu|dortu|dort|dorte|dortu|dortem |dorty|dortů|dortům|dorty|dorty|dortech|dorty }} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|cs|čokoládový dort}} * {{l|cs|dortík}} * {{l|cs|dortíček}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:PSJC}} * {{R:SSJC}} [[Category:cs:Cakes and pastries]] ---- ==French== ===Pronunciation=== * {{fr-IPA|pos=v}} ===Verb=== {{head|fr|verb form}} # {{inflection of|fr|dormir||3|s|pres|indc}} ===Anagrams=== * {{l|fr|tord}} ---- ==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|dorten}} {{qualifier|dialectal or poetic; overall very rare}} ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|doret}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/dɔrt/|[dɔʁt]|[dɔɐ̯t]|[dɔːt]}} * {{audio|de|De-dort.ogg|audio}} ===Adverb=== {{head|de|adverb}} # [[there]], [[yonder]] ====Usage notes==== * '''Dort''' is seldom ever heard in non-formal speech in some regions of Germany, chiefly the west and north. The synonym {{m|de|da}} is overall more frequent, although ''dort'' is quite common in eastern Germany, southern Germany, and Austria. * In literary German, '''dort''' is usual in all regions. ====Synonyms==== * {{l|de|da}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
